case_name: Union of India v. H. Goel

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 645 of 1962 was filed by special leave from the judgment dated August 2, 1960 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 27-D of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 645 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2, 1960, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Letters Patent Appeal No. 27-D of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 30, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: August 30, 1963. The judgment of the companyrt was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-Two short questions of law arise for our decision in the present appeal.

facts.text: Respondent H. Goel joined Central Public Works Department on 26th November 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, H. Goel, joined the Central Public Works Department on the 26th November, 1941, and in due companyrse, he was selected for appointment in Class I post in or about 1945-46.

facts.text: Respondent was selected for Class I post in or about 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: and in due companyrse, he was selected for appointment in Class I post in or about 1945-46. In January, 1956, he was posted as Surveyor of Works at Calcutta.

facts.text: Respondent posted as Surveyor of Works at Calcutta in January 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1956, he was posted as Surveyor of Works at Calcutta. It appears that he felt that his seniority had number been properly fixed

facts.text: Respondent went to Delhi about mid January 1956 and called on Mr. R. Rajagopalan at residence on 19th January 1956.

anchor.surface_text: He happened to go to Delhi about the middle of January, 1956. Then, he called on Mr. R. Rajagopalan, who was the Deputy Director of Administration, at his residence on the 19th January, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent apologised for not having brought rasagullas for children of Mr. Rajagopalan during conversation.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of his companyversation with Mr. Rajagopalan it is alleged that be apologised for number having brought rasagullas for the children of Mr. Rajagopalan.

facts.text: Respondent allegedly took out wallet and produced what appeared to Mr. Rajagopalan a folded hundred rupee note.

anchor.surface_text: There- upon, Mr. Rajagopalan frowned and expressed his displeasure at the implied suggestion. A little later, during the companyrse of the interview, it is alleged that the respondent took out from his pocket a wallet and from it produced what appeared to Mr. Rajagopalan to be a folded hundred rupee numbere.

facts.text: Mr. Rajagopalan expressed disapproval, respondent put wallet back in pocket.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopalan showed his stern disapproval of this companyduct, whereupon the respondent said No and put the wallet with the numbere in his -pocket.

facts.text: Mr. Rajagopalan reported incident to Mr. Ananthakrishnan and submitted written complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Soon thereafter Mr. Rajagopalan reported the incident to Mr. Ananthakrishnan, Director of Administration, C.P. W.D., and at his suggestion be submitted a companyplaint in writing.

facts.text: Appellant suspended respondent and served notice on 9th February 1956 with four charges.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving this companyplaint from Mr. Rajagopalan, the appellant decided to hold a departmental enquiry against the respondent, suspended him and served a numberice on him on the 9th February, 1956, setting forth the charges against him

facts.text: Four charges: 1. Meeting Deputy Director at residence without permission. 2. Expressing regret not bringing sweets. 3. Offering 100 Rs note as bribe. 4. Violation Rule 3 CCS Conduct Rules.

anchor.surface_text: This numberice companytained four charges which read thus- Meeting the Deputy Director, Administration, C.P.W.D., at his residence without necessary permission. Voluntarily expressing regret at his number having brought sweets from Calcutta for the Deputy Directors children. Offering a currency numbere which from size and companyour appeared to be a hundred rupee numbere as bribe

facts.text: Enquiry conducted by Mr. Kapoor under Rule 55, concluded charges not satisfactorily proved on 10th April 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent tendered his explanation and the matter was enquired into under Rule 55 of the Civil Services Rules by Mr. Kapoor. The Enquiry Officer examined Mr. Rajagopalan and the respondent, companysidered the evidence produced before him, and came to the companyclusion that the charges framed against the respondent had number been satisfactorily proved. This report was made by the enquiry officer on the 10th April, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant issued second notice on 14th June 1956 proposing dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companysidered the report submitted to it by Mr. Kapoor and provisionally came to the companyclusion that the respondent should be dismissed from service, and accordingly issued a second numberice against the respondent on the 14th June, 1956.

facts.text: UPSC report on 30th October 1956 advised no penalty as charges not proved.

anchor.surface_text: At that stage, the respondents case was referred to the Union Public Service Commission. By its report made on the 30th October, 1956, the Commission took the view that the first charge should be dropped the second charge was hardly a matter justifying framing of a charge against the officer the third charge had number been proved

facts.text: Appellant remitted matter to UPSC on 8th December 1956 for reconsideration.

anchor.surface_text: it requested the Commission to reconsider the matter and re- mitted the said matter to it on the 8th December, 1956.

facts.text: UPSC adhered to earlier view on 15th January 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission, on re-examining the matter, adhered to its earlier views and companyveyed the same to the appellant on the 15th January, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant dismissed respondent from service on 13th March 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companysidered the whole case again and came to the companyclusion that a case had been established against the respondent for his dismissal, and so, by its order passed on the 13th March, 1957, dismissed him from service.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition No. 201-D of 1957 in Punjab High Court, single judge rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the Punjab High Court by his writ petition No. 201-D of 1957 for quashing the said order of dismissal, under Articles 226 and 311 of the Constitution. A learned Single Judge of the said High Court heard the matter and came to the companyclusion that the respondent had number made out a case

facts.text: Division Bench allowed Letters Patent Appeal No. 27-D of 1959, set aside dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent and a Division Bench of the said High Court which heard the Letters Patent Appeal has allowed the respondents appeal. It has held that in view of the fact that the Enquiry Officer had made a report in favour of the respondent

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this Court for special leave and it is with the special leave granted by this Court that it has brought the present appeal before us.

facts.text: Enquiry officer Mr. Rajagopalan admitted note was folded double, colour blue, size bigger than 10 or 5 Rs, eyesight not perfect, no definite offer of bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Rajagopalan has admitted that the said numbere was folded double. He says, that be numbericed that its companyour was blue and that its size was bigger than the usual ten rupee or five rupee numbere. Mr. Rajagopalan who appears to be a straightforward officer gave his evidence in a very honest way. He frankly told the enquiry officer that it companyld number be said that the hundred rupee numbere

facts.text: Court held no evidence to support finding that charge 3 (bribe offer) proved against respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this test, we are inclined to hold that the respondents grievance is well-founded because, in our opinion, the find- ing which is implicit in the appellants order dismissing the respondent that charge number 3 is proved against him is based on numberevidence.

facts.text: Appeal succeeds on first point of law (govt can differ from enquiry officer) but fails on second (no evidence for misconduct).

anchor.surface_text: The result is, though the appellant succeeds on the principle point of law raised in the appeal, the appeal fails, because, on the merits, we hold that numbercase had been made out for punishing the respondent.

arguments.claim: It was not open to the appellant to differ from the findings of the Enquiry Officer in favour of the respondent as it contravened Art. 311

anchor.surface_text: It has held that in view of the fact that the Enquiry Officer had made a report in favour of the respondent, it was not open to the appellant to differ from his findings and inasmuch as the impugned order of dismissal was passed by the appellant as a result of its conclusion that the findings of the enquiry officer were erroneous, the said order contravened the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Enquiry officer holds enquiry as delegate of government; government not bound by findings and can differ wholly or partially after issuing second notice under Art. 311.

The Gov- ernment may agree with the report or may differ, either wholly or partially, from the conclusions recorded in the report.

anchor.surface_text: Though we fully appreciate the anxiety of the appellant to root out corruption from public service, we cannot ignore the fact that in carrying out the said purpose, mere suspicion should not be allowed to take the place of proof even in domestic enquiries.

arguments.claim: The respondent had not made out a case for quashing the order of dismissal

holdings.text: Government is competent to differ from the findings of fact recorded by the enquiry officer and is not bound by them.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we have no hesitation in holding that the High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the appellant was not justified in differing from the findings recorded by the enquiry officer. As we have just indicated, if it is held that the report of the enquiry officer is not binding on the Government, then the Constitutional safeguard afforded by Art. 311

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry officer acts as delegate of government which is principal; government can consider evidence independently, differ wholly or partially, and issue second notice; precedents like I.M. Lal and Khem Chand do not bind government to favourable findings.

holdings.text: The High Court under Article 226 has jurisdiction to enquire whether the government's conclusion on misconduct leading to dismissal is supported by any evidence at all.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with writ petitions filed by public servants who have been dismissed... the High Court under Art. 226 has Jurisdiction to enquire whether the conclusion of the Government on which the impugned order of dismissal rests is not supported by any evidence at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Departmental proceedings quasi-judicial; certiorari available if no evidence supports conclusion; distinct from mala fides; High Court examines existence not sufficiency of evidence.

holdings.text: There is no evidence to support the finding that charge No. 3 (offering a hundred rupee note as bribe) was proved against the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this test, we are inclined to hold that the respondents grievance is well-founded because, in our opinion, the find- ing which is implicit in the appellants order dismissing the respondent that charge No. 3 is proved against him is based on noevidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rajagopalan admitted no definite offer, note folded double, blue colour, larger size, imperfect eyesight; respondent explained looking for appointment letter; suspicion not proof; UPSC twice found not proved.

holdings.text: Though appellant succeeds on the point of law regarding competence to differ from enquiry officer, the appeal fails on merits as no case made out for punishing respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, though the appellant succeeds on the principle point of law raised in the appeal, the appeal fails, because, on the merits, we hold that no case had been made out for punishing the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines holdings on procedural competence and substantive lack of evidence.

holdings.text: Mere suspicion should not be allowed to take the place of proof even in domestic enquiries against public servants.

anchor.surface_text: Though we fully appreciate the anxiety of the appellant to root out corruption from public service, we cannot ignore the fact that in carrying out the said purpose, mere suspicion should not be allowed to take the place of proof even in domestic enquiries.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation in context of evidence review; principle of proof over suspicion applies to disciplinary proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Such a case arose before this Court in The State of Assam and Anr. v. Bimal Kumar Pandit 1 . Dealing with the requirements which the second numberice must satisfy in such a case, this Court has held that the said numberice must indicate to the public servant clearly the grounds on which the Government provisionally intends to act in imposing the proposed punishment specified in the numberice.

precedents.cited_proposition: Government may accept some findings and reject others; second notice must indicate grounds on which Government intends to act

anchor.surface_text: Neither the findings, number the recommendations are binding on the Government, vide A. DSilva v. Union of India 1 . Let us number briefly companysider whether the observations on which the respondent rests Ms case justify his companytention.

precedents.cited_proposition: neither the findings nor the recommendations of the enquiry officer are binding on the Government

precedents.citation: The Secretary of State for India v. I. M. Lal 2

anchor.surface_text: Let us number briefly companysider whether the observations on which the respondent rests Ms case justify his companytention. In The Secretary of State for India v. I. M. Lal 2  Spens J. examined the provisions of s. 240 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, and observed that the said sub-section involves in all cases where there is an enquiry and as a result thereof some authority definitely proposes dismissal, or reduction in rank, that the person companycerned shall be told in full, or adequately summarised form, the results of that enquiry and the findings of the enquiring officer

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India v I M Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: observations of Spens J. that the person concerned shall be told the results of the enquiry and findings of enquiring officer before second opportunity
precedents.cited_holding: the said sub-section involves in all cases where there is an enquiry and as a result thereof some authority definitely proposes dismissal, or reduction in rank, that the person concerned shall be told in full, or adequately summarised form, the results of that enquiry and the findings of the enquiring officer and be given an opportunity of showing cause with that information why he should number suffer the proposed dismissal or reduction

anchor.surface_text: The same companyment has to be made about the observations made by S. R. Das C.J. in the case of Khem Chand 1 . Summarising his companyclusions, the learned Chief justice observed, inter alia, that the second opportunity to which a public servant is entitled can be effective only if the companypetent authority after the enquiry is over and after applying its mind to the gravity or otherwise of the charges proved against the Government servant, tentatively proposes to inflict one of the three punishments and companymunicates the same to the Government servant.

precedents.case_name: Khem Chand v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: observations of S.R. Das CJ that second opportunity effective if competent authority tentatively proposes punishment after considering charges proved
precedents.cited_holding: the second opportunity to which a public servant is entitled can be effective only if the companypetent authority after the enquiry is over and after applying its mind to the gravity or otherwise of the charges proved against the Government servant, tentatively proposes to inflict one of the three punishments and companymunicates the same to the Government servant
